title: What is your favorite food? Why do you like it so much? - Quora

response.answer_text: From Helmand Palace in San Francisco: Aush Soup, Aushak Appetizer, Mourgh (chicken) KababFrom Roti Indian Bistro in San Francisco: Chicken Tikka Masala with Pulao Basmati Rice, Vegetable Samosas, Chicken Pakoras, Prawn Biriyani, Mango Lassi, Green Mint Chutney, Red Hot-Sauce Chutney (based on a habanero-like pepper)From Marnee Thai in San Francisco: Red Curry Chicken (with white or brown rice), Tom Kha Gai (chicken/coconut) Soup, Golden Triangle Vegetable Samosas, Chicken Satay (with peanut sauce)From Bistro Burger in San Francisco: Classic Bistro Burger (medium-well done beef patty, with lettuce and fresh/raw onion ONLY — no cheese, no sauces)From Boulevard in San Francisco: Soup of the Day (especially if it’s Lobster Bisque), Ahi Tuna Tartare (appetizer), Grilled Halibut or Sea Bass or Salmon main course, possibly a dessert rich in chocolate and/or vanilla-beanFrom Prospect in San Francisco: Soup of the Day (especially if it’s Lobster Bisque), Ahi Tuna Tartare (appetizer), Seared Sea Scallops over golden risottoCuisine of Nepal in San Francisco: Lamb Samosas, Chicken Soup (spicy, with lentils), Cashew Cream Curry Chicken (with white rice), Masala Chai TeaSens in San Francisco: Moroccan Lemon Chicken Soup, 38-Degree Latitude Roasted Chicken Breast, Lamb Burger (medium-well-done meat patty, cheese and sauces on the side)Oasis Lebanese Cuisine in SW Beaverton, OR: Hummus Plate, Sambousik, Zatar Pizza, Chicken Kebab with rice and vegetables, Kafta Kabab with rice and vegetables, Rosewater LemonadeVista Spring Cafe in Portland, OR: Bowl of Clam Chowder, Vista Combo PizzaThere are plenty of others, but this question asked for only 10. A few of my others not on this list might easily be good enough to displace something on this list, but these are the ones which came to mind first. (Other restaurants include R&G Lounge in SF, Georgio’s in Portland, The Fish Market in Palo Alto and in San Mateo, Kabul Afghan Cuisine in San Carlos, El Charrito taqueria in San Carlos, Mifune (sushi) in Japantown Center in SF, Scoma’s at Pier 47 in SF, Fresca Peruvian Cuisine in SF (West Portal and Noe Valley), Lupa (Italian) in Noe Valley SF, Bacco in Noe Valley SF, La Ciccia at Church/30th in SF, North Beach Restaurant in SF, E Tutta Qua in SF, Gialina in Glen Park SF, Nostrana in Portland, Swagat Indian Cuisine in Beaverton, Dundee Bistro in Dundee (OR), Karam in Portland, Picaro in the Mission in SF, Pak-Wan Pakistani/Indian Cuisine in the Mission in SF.)

They’re all my favorites, I just like some more than others. Over a lifetime, it’s important to try everything, because at one (or two) main meal/day, times 365 days per year, multiplied by 40–50 years, it allows for many opportunities to try different cuisines. Italian, French, Spanish, German, Chinese, Middle-Eastern, Japanese, Eastern European, Mexican, Thai and the broad spectrum of American “fusion” all together make a great base to work from, and that still leaves dozens more to try. Nearly each Caribbean Island has its own specialties. Fish/shellfish, beef, lamb, pork, fowl, wild game, vegetables, fruits, cheeses & dairy can all be prepared in many different manners, there are dozens of types of stews, alone. Throw in burgers, steaks, roasts, sandwiches, pockets, panini and Cuban sandwiches, etc., and it makes for a wonderful base with opportunity to explore & experiment. Traveling helps to expand opportunities to create an even more diverse diet, also - eating is almost as big a part of traveling as is seeing new & beautiful sights. What was my favorite 40 years ago is different from 35 years ago, 30, 20, and so on, so I could even give different answers from day to day. Sometimes, just a charcuterie, antipasto or sashimi plate, and other times a prime rib roast, pork, veal or beef roast or traditional formal meat dish from any nation can be my favorite, at that particular time; other times, a bowl of soup and an appetizer or two can make an exceptional meal. Add different types of breads, rolls, meat-filled baked goods and there are dozens of other options. Think of the hundreds of different cheeses, alone, that are available. Meals of egg dishes provide omelettes, frittatas, quiches and many other varieties of food to enjoy, along with waffles, pancakes, Johnnycakes and many other such foods, too, and then there are dozens of varieties of potatoes alone, not to mention other vegetable main courses, such as stuffed peppers, stuffed zucchini, etc. Plus, soups are extremely varied from country to country, as are noodles and pasta or varieties of rice. I could go on for hours; food is so cool, it’s not just for survival and sustenance, each meal can be a true experience, almost like short trips to exotic places, but a meal doesn’t have to be expensive or elaborate, if well thought-out, and viewed as an experience.
